item.title: 'Chronic' street clutter makes London 'worse place to live,' report finds
item.description: Think twice before you drop your Pret cup onto a rubbish pile on the pavement As a global and capital city, Londonâ€™s pavements may not be pedestrian-friendly, potentially earning it the title of a â€œworse placeâ€ to live, a report finds. The study, titled â€œReducing Street Clutter in Central London,â€ evaluated Goodge Street in W1, Charing Cross Road in WC2, and Belvedere Road in SE1. It revealed that nearly half of the street clutter (47 per cent), including E-bikes, rubbish bags, and bollards, h

item.title: Finally, someone has created an tube map with how stations are actually pronounced
item.description: Donâ€™t lie â€“ youâ€™ve definitely dared an international student to say â€˜Leicester Squareâ€™ before London Underground is an iconic signature of the country with a long history. Created in 1931, the map has evolved throughout the time with new stations, new colours indicating tube lines, and expanding its system to more of Londonâ€™s zones. However, non-English speakers may struggle with the stationâ€™s name, with few words and place names pronounced phonetically. Arcangelo Martiello, an Italian, has t

item.title: Ghost Island with UNESCO Awards, History of Salt Industry and Makingï½œYim Tin Tsai
item.description: Yim Tin Tsai was once a desolate island, but it has received two UNESCO Asia-Pacific Awards. Despite being Hakka, the residents follow Catholicism. This video will introduce Hong Kong's salt industry, as well as the Hakka and Catholic cultures in Yim Tin Tsai, providing you with a glimpse into the diverse facets of Hong Kong.

item.title: Former Capital at Seaside Community, Oldest and Smallest Post Officeï½œStanley
item.description: Stanley today is a seaside tourist destination: beaches, sunshine, and markets; Stanley, with its holiday atmosphere, was once the administrative centre of Hong Kong Island and a military stronghold. It is also home to some historic sites, such as the oldest functioning post office in Hong Kong. This video will introduce Stanley's attractions, taking you back to the Victorian era of British Hong Kong.

item.title: Abandoned Industrial Building, Slaughterhouse Renewed as Artist Villageï½œ13 Streets
item.description: Before reclamation, Ma Tau Kok was the cape of To Kwa Wan. In the 1950s, Hong Kong's manufacturing industry flourished; thus, its economy developed rapidly, becoming one of the 'four Asian tigers'. Despite the 'Tong lau' on 13 Streets To Kwa Wan having colourful wall designs, the community has been abandoned due to the economic transformation. This video will share you the Hong Kong's industrial period in the past.

item.title: Pirate Stronghold and Quarry Siteï½œLei Yue Mun fishing village
item.description: Lei Yue Mun fishing village has a history spanning over 150 years, with its origins dating back to the Qing Dynasty and the British colonial era in Hong Kong. This video will share you how Lei Yue Mun fishing village has changed throughout times and how policy shape today's culture there.

item.title: Creation Without Emotion: the Controversies of AI Art â€”
item.description: If youâ€™ve been online recently, itâ€™s hard to miss the plethora of AI-made content that seems to be on the rise nowadays. In particular, AI art generators have become a futuristic new trend both in the creative and social online spheres. However, despite its seemingly innocent appearance, it has also sparked controversy and raised ethical concerns around its infringement on the creative industry and data protection of images, which are widely shared by creators, artists, and the general public.

item.title: UCL Provost Admits University Is Underpaying Staff â€” Pi Media
item.description: There are several strikes happening in the United Kingdom, including in universities, partially due to inflation being at its highest level in 40 years. UCL has admitted that it has systematically underpaid staff for many years, a situation that may lead to deprivation of education in the near future even in the case of a highly-ranked university. Michael Spence, the president of UCL, told the Times Higher Educationâ€™s THE Campus Live event: â€œWeâ€™ve balanced the books by hugely increasing numbers

item.title: Let the Blank Papers Tell - How Protesters Express Themselves With No Freedom of Speech â€”
item.description: The largest protest in China, after the Tiananmen Square Massacre in 1989, is happening against the Zero-Covid policy where protesters hold a blank sheet of white paper known as â€˜A4 Revolutionâ€™ or â€˜White Paper Protestsâ€™. This has caught the attention of social media and is thought of as new and creative. On 24th November, a burning building in Urumqi caused 10 death tolls in which residents could not escape flames due to strict lockdown policies since last August. The tragedy angered the people

item.title: Students Report More Ongoing Problems at One Pool Street â€” Pi Media
item.description: The first term has nearly come to an end, but students living at One Pool Street - a UCL brand new accommodation - are still struggling with poor living conditions. One Pool Street is a self-catered hall for undergraduates and postgraduate students on the UCL East campus, which was scheduled to open last September. However, due to technical issues, students could not move in and were instead assigned to temporary halls â€“ John Dodgson House, The Gantry London, Hyatt Regency Hotel Stratford, and

item.title: The Untold Struggles: Taiwanâ€™s Medical Teamâ€™s Battle Against COVID-19
item.description: When coronavirus (COVID-19) made its unwelcome entrance in 2019, the medical community braced itself for a new wave of challenges. The memories of SARS still fresh, Taiwanâ€™s medical professionals stood at the frontline once again, ready to confront this formidable enemy. To address the growing number of suspicious Covid-19 cases, a public hospital in Taipei made the difficult decision to convert its non-infectious disease unit, specifically the department of oncology, into isolation wards. Howe

item.title: Having Cultural Exchange with International Students in Taiwan!
item.description: To know more about how international students live in Taiwan, this article will share their interesting stories, including students from China, Malaysia, Thailand, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines at National Chengchi University. â€˜Being a student here has completely fulfilled my expectation towards university life since I was small.â€™ said Chong from Shanghai University, who enjoys the student life here, such as engaging in different activities â€” Photo Club, Taiwan and Mainland Exchange Asso
